thread.title: From the Elders to the Kids: What I Wish I’d Known
thread.title_full: From the Elders to the Kids: What I Wish I’d Known - The New York Times

title: From the Elders to the Kids: What I Wish I’d Known
text:
Share This Page   Video Millennials Ask: What's It Like to Retire? We asked journalism students around the country to talk to seniors about retirement. This is what they recorded.
By STUDENT JOURNALISTS on Publish Date March 3, 2017. . Watch in Times Video » embed When you’re in college, retirement seems so far away. How do you even wrap your head around it? We asked journalism students from five colleges and universities to talk with retirees, and find out what they wish they had known when they were the students’ age. The conversations have been edited.
Photo Lucille Biondi and Grant Viola Lucille Biondi, 93 
Spot welder at Junior Toy 
Retired at 60 
Macon, Mo. 
“I like to work. If a job was open, I’d go back right now and apply for a job. At 93. I would ask to work about 3 hours a day.”
By Grant Viola, Ohio University
Photo Brad Baznik and Megan Magensky Brad Baznik, 58 
Tech support for wireless services 
Retired at 55 
Naperville, Ill. 
“You’re going to want to plan, especially if you’re married and have children … You’ve got to start thinking about how long you want to stay in your house, if you’re going to stay in your house forever? Do you want to be close to where your children are living? How long is your spouse going to work?”
By Megan Magensky, Columbia College Chicago
Photo Gerald Bernabei and Bianca Cahue Gerald Bernabei, 76 Manager of farm services/farmer 
Retired (sort of) at 67 
Lowell, Ill. 
“I was farming about 1,200 acres my whole career until I just kind of retired about 10 years ago. But I still farm over 450 acres … Health is the biggest factor. If you’re healthy and stay active, you’ll do well.”
By Bianca Cahue, Columbia College Chicago
Photo Travis Newsome and Maria Cardona Travis Newsome, 67 Finance 
Retired at 60 
Chicago 
“Retirement is not a place where you go to prepare to die, but instead a place where you just go to prepare to live. I did not know that 65 would be the new 40, and had I known that, I would have been less stressed about retirement.”
By Maria Cardona, Columbia College Chicago
Photo Lauren Dunn and Susan Jeng Susan Jeng, 75 Accountant for automotive parts company 
Retired at 51 
Anaheim, Calif. 
“The most important thing when you want to have a happy retirement life is to have a good relationship with your spouse. I think we have a wonderful relationship. We go travel together, we see our friends together and we do things together.”
By Lauren Dunn, University of Southern California
Photo Ed Grimsley and Giovanni Moujaes Ed Grimsley, 67 Education service officer in the Marines 
Retired at 67 
San Diego 
“The millennials are not all bad. It is what it is. But it’s up to us to mentor them, to make sure they’re doing the right thing and become better assets to the American people, and to this country.”
By Giovanni Moujaes, University of Southern California
Photo Anna Jane Howell and Tony Leger Tony Leger, 73 Fuel distributor 
Retired at 65 
Baton Rouge, La. 
“Do I miss it? Yes. I don’t believe there is a week that passes that I don’t dream about it ... But when I tell the wife in the morning, ‘I dreamed about delivering fuel,’ and she says ‘Pop, would you like to do it again?’ I say ‘No.’”
By Anna Jane Howell, Louisiana State University
Photo Tina Rico and Margarito Rodriguez Margarito Rodriguez, 82 Air Force/federal government employee 
Retired at 62 
Austin, Tex. 
“Start thinking about 40 years from now or so. And what are you going to be doing? … Because when I was growing up, I did not think about what I was going to do … I kept thinking it was too early to think about retirement, and I believe that that was wrong.”
By Tina Rico, University of Texas at Austin
